conclusion: Use the ideal gas law and the relationship \( \frac{pV}{T} = \text{constant} \) for the process.

Identify given values from the p-V diagram: State C: \( p_C = 5 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \) m\(^3\), \( T_C = 300 \) K; State A: \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_A = 5 \times 10^{-3} \) m\(^3\).
Apply the ideal gas law: \( \frac{p_C V_C}{T_C} = \frac{p_A V_A}{T_A} \).

Substitute known values into the equation: \( \frac{(5 \times 10^5 \ \text{Pa}) \times (2 \times 10^{-3} \ \text{m}^3)}{300 \ \text{K}} = \frac{(3 \times 10^5 \ \text{Pa}) \times (5 \times 10^{-3} \ \text{m}^3)}{T_A} \).
Simplify and solve for \( T_A \): \( \frac{1 \ \text{J}}{30 \ \text{K}} = \frac{15 \ \text{J}}{T_A} \), leading to \( T_A = 450 \ \text{K} \).
The temperature of the gas in state A is \( \boxed{450 \ \text{K}} \).
